I had a lot more fun than I was expecting, but still not sure if it's all that good. Sure it's mean (as all the comments will agree on), but also very procedural to keep turn phases in order. Which means dealmaking isn't as freeform as it could've been, and I'm thinking of other negotiation games that are possibly meaner and more flexible.

I'm most reminded of Chinatown, but enjoyed this more because of more amusing backstabbing. You can math out the revenue streams, but at least in this game the majority of the game are the negotiations, as opposed to only 1/3 of Chinatown being lively. But then it falls apart in the endgame the same way, it's too predictable how things will go (aaah, eurogame negotiations).

So it has the same flaw where only money is up for grabs, but makes up for it because hiring another player is possible, so at least there's a few dimensions. This means betrayal is pretty much mandatory. This is why I didn't find it overly mean myself, it was the game forcing me to pick one candidate, but I imagine for a lot of eurogamers this is super-aggressive.

Seems to me like a response to Knizia's Quo Vadis, just not as good because it's obsessed with accounting. Also not as good as I'm The Boss, where the payout split is directly negotiated (and lots of wackiness can happen). And Cosmic Encounter is nonstop chaos in every direction. For more casual audiences, Bohnanza is generally nicer, simpler to learn, and its looser structure actually allows more creativity to blossom. So this one has mean negotiation, but.... not that hilarious, it's actually overly serious because the end result is counting money. It's just hard to keep track of who has the money because of all the bribes being thrown about (even if some of them aren't acted on). Still, I liked it more than a lot of other eurogame negotiation titles, which have no life at all.

My initial reaction to Intrigue's sales pitch was a mix of "The spirit of Diplomacy in 45 minutes? Where do I sign?" and, upon a further read of the rules, confusion regarding the symmetry of both the initial game state and the actions available to players. I hoped that turn order - and the resulting asynchronous timing of payouts - would be enough to carve interesting situations, but it turns out that my worries were founded: 3 players agreeing to give away every non-minimal position to each other for the minimal bribe until a couple rounds of wages have paid out will basically roflstomp the first half of the game and (barring any bribe attempt from other players) that team will enjoy a risk-free joint first place with maximal income and only two opponents left to worry about. While from that point on, the game has yet to be decided and there is actual gameplay, it's ultimately the consequence of a fairly boring "setup" which has arbitrarily put another 1-2 players out of contention.

One may argue "What if one member of the triad backstabs their companions by accepting another offer?", but early betrayal is generally suboptimal in negotiation games for two reasons: you're building yourself a reputation for future games of being untrustworthy from the get-go, and for that game you're the leading player with a bull's-eye on your forehead and too many turns left to hope you won't get dethroned in response. Speaking of the latter, although the nature of non-binding agreements prevents arithmetics from completely taking over, it's unsurprising that the official game rules attempt to hide the relative rank of players and the calculation of endgame values behind (drumroll) hidden money.

In order to win, you have to lie and treason, but as you have so many freedom to make decisions, you cannot hide behind the excuse of "I backstabbed you because it was the optimal move".

As a result, this game literally enrages people.

I love negotiation games, and I ought to like this one....

But the issue is this game seems to think backstabbing and betrayal somehow win negotiation games...but they really don't. Yes, at some point you generally need to to get the upper hand, but prior to that, ruthless cooperation by some parties will propel them to a much stronger spot over their other opponents.

It's not different here. Players that work together can easily get and protect strong income spots, and defecting too early is not rewarded as they'll just get cut out and beat down. So the game is fun for those players who have to figure out and time the right spot to make their break and try to get in the lead, but it just kind of sucks for those that have wound up on the outside.

Fascinating hidden gem of trivially simple rules and chaotic negotiation. You're attempting to secure high-paying positions in your opponents' mansions, but so are other players, so you're attempting to one-up them with bribes and quid pro quo promises that are almost impossible to hold up.

I'm a big fan of negotiation games in general, and this is just pure negotiation through and through, but the deals and promises in this just seem to get so tangled and convoluted as the game progresses (which is probably by design!), and with people trying to optimize their deal-making on every turn, this game stretches far beyond the listed time of 45 mins.

I was ultimately happy to play this, but would probably prefer to play Chinatown/Waterfall Park or Zoo Vadis in this genre, just because of how much more group-dependent this game is and how deals are much more tangible in those games, which also makes those games run a lot smoother.

It's a negotiation game, so that tracks that it was supposed to be mean, as I've rarely seen a game that focuses on that mechanic that isn't mean. The game centers around trying to acquire income generating positions from other players. That way you get these positions is by offering bribes to that player. The mean part comes from the fact that the player receiving the bribes must take all bribes offered, but is not obliged to keep any promises that were exchanged with that bribe. It's very easy to lose a pile of money based on mixed motivations between different parties, and even securing such an income position is not even secure, as it can be given away later. This was very lean and very clean, almost too much so for my taste. I did like it, but it quickly became a game that I would play but never seek out on my own.

It's a miracle that it even works and I think it falls apart completely if players aren't willing engage at least a little with its spirit. It really wants to be this sly, cutthroat game: the cover art, the dramatic examples of betrayal the rulebook and so on. But contrary to what others say, I felt that you really have to bring your own meanness. If you bring too little or too much I don't see it being very enjoyable at all.

Anyway, the game is great fun when it works. Drags on a little too long towards the end; though that, as every other aspect of it, will be very group dependent.

It still happens every now and then that I discover an under the radar game that gets the full five stars. 30 year old Intrigue is such a hidden gem. I have not laughed so hard during a game in a while.

Intrigue is truly simple. In your turn you collect your wages, allocate job applicants at your castle and send your own workers to other player's castles. The winner is the player with the most money after 6 rounds.

The heart of the game is accepting or rejecting job applicants at your castle. Since any worker in your castle will earn income for the player owning the worker, you will want some favours back from the other player. Time to start negotiating!

The natural thing is to demand monetary compensation for hiring a worker. If you both agree the other player has to pay you the money and then it is up to you: do you stick to your promise, or do you give the worker a lower paying job or do you simply dispel the worker to Elba or some other undefined prison island colony?

Not keeping your promise will cost you your reputation of course. And it most likely will affect your chances elsewhere where your workers will need to be negotiated to work and earn income. But being deceitful at one point becomes a necessity. And the other players may be untrustworthy, but not dealing with them may cost you more! This is where the discomfort starts to kick in.

The player you trusted so much is starting to earn too much income, and now there is a new job applicant from another (untrustworthy) player that could kick the trusted player out of the job at your castle. Will you reward deceitfulness and punish trustworthiness? Was the relationship really mutually beneficial and truly built on trust, or just exploitative leeching? Or will you keep up the pretense, only to extort some more money out of your "ally", before dumping them?

It is hard to keep a straight face, and you must be able to remember it is just a game where betrayal and deceit are the core of the game. Laugh it all off! And if you cannot, then this game is not for you.

Intrigue is about inevitable deceit and it requires activating an uncomfortable dark side of yourself. It probably works best in a group of people that you know and trust. Intrigue is a deviously delightful game of pure negotiation.
The core mechanics are so simple that players will already be cutting deals before you finish explaining the rules, though I should say that it is much better with some house rules eliminating minimum bribes and making negotiation more freeform.

The beginning of the game feels very open; the world is your oyster and you could happily make friends and spend almost any sum for a short-term gains...
...But as each round passes the stakes get higher, the board becomes claustrophobic, and negotiations become increasingly stressful.
By the end you'll be yelling, bargaining, and breaking deals while swearing your loyalties up and down just to eek out an extra buck.

Tight design, no random chance, constant player interaction, and short enough that no matter how heated it gets it'll soon be over and everyone can decompress and laugh together. I love the story the players tell together through their dickering.
